sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Spyware like Pegasus and Predator, used by European countries to spy on politicians, journalists and citizens must have stricter regulations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: That's the main takeaway from the European Parliament Committee that's carried out a year-long investigation into member states and the use of spyware.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: MEPs from the committee are making clear that spyware is what they are calling a threat to democracy and should only be used under strict conditions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We need to make sure that it can only be used in very strictly limited conditions to fight terrorism, to fight organized crime. Any abuse of it directly undermines democracy in the EU, directly undermines the rule of law and all governments have a responsibility to counter this. And looking at the way member states have cooperated with the investigation, I think we can be critical towards all member states for not really cooperating with the work that we wanted to do.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The final report from the PEGA committee includes specific recommendations for five countries where the use of malicious spyware has been identified. In Hungary and Poland, the governments have dismantled independent oversight mechanisms and are being asked to restore judicial independence.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: In Greece, spyware has been used for political and financial gain. Cyprus is also accused of exporting the technology to third countries. And in Spain, the report asks for a fair investigation into 47 cases where it's unclear who authorised the deployment of the spyware.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: One of the MEPs in charge of the investigation told Euronews that throughout the process she was pressured by national interests who were trying to influence, delay and even block the committee's work.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: But you know what, if we tolerate in the European Union that journalists are being spied on with spyware, lawyers, government critics, opposition politicians, but even members of governing parties who are then being blackmailed, if we accept that then democracy is dead. The concerned member states have till the end of the year to abide by the new conditions otherwise the European Parliament is asking that these spyware technologies be banned.
